channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: College Art Professor Challenges Students To Build Insect Motels
item.description: May 30, 2017 - A concerned University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee art instructor challenged her students to construct insect motels out of natural, untreated materials. Each motel must provide an appropriate habitat for a particular insect and attract human interest too, as each has a QR Code with information about why that bug or bee matters in nature and needs to be nurtured. Nearly 100 are installed in a state park overlooking Lake Michigan in downtown Milwaukee.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 30, 2017 - A concerned University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee art instructor challenged her students to construct insect motels out of natural, untreated materials. Each motel must provide an appropriate habitat for a particular insect and attract human interest too, as each has a QR Code with information about why that bug or bee matters in nature and needs to be nurtured. Nearly 100 are installed in a state park overlooking Lake Michigan in downtown Milwaukee. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/30/530769818/college-art-professor-challenges-students-to-build-insect-motels

item.title: Are State Rules For Treating Sepsis Really Saving Lives?
item.description: May 30, 2017 - Some states dictate how doctors must treat this life-threatening reaction to infection, and early intervention is helping. But scientific evidence may be changing too rapidly for the rules to keep up.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 30, 2017 - Some states dictate how doctors must treat this life-threatening reaction to infection, and early intervention is helping. But scientific evidence may be changing too rapidly for the rules to keep up. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/30/530224517/are-state-rules-for-treating-sepsis-really-saving-lives

item.title: How A Theory Of Crime And Policing Was Born, And Went Terribly Wrong
item.description: May 29, 2017 - Decades ago, researchers introduced a new theory of policing. It's called "broken windows" and is seen by many as a cure-all for crime. But the idea is often used in ways its creators never intended.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 29, 2017 - Decades ago, researchers introduced a new theory of policing. It's called "broken windows" and is seen by many as a cure-all for crime. But the idea is often used in ways its creators never intended. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/29/530192364/how-a-theory-of-crime-and-policing-was-born-and-went-terribly-wrong

item.title: How An Interview With A Shark Researcher Wound Up Starring A Shark
item.description: May 29, 2017 - Why have dozens of great white sharks turned up around Southern California beaches recently? Finding the answer led to a close-up view of a baby great white shark — and the researcher who caught her.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 29, 2017 - Why have dozens of great white sharks turned up around Southern California beaches recently? item.title: Handshake-Free Zones Target Spread Of Germs In The Hospital
item.description: May 29, 2017 - Hospital-acquired infections can be life-threatening, and unwashed hands are often to blame. One hospital in California thinks banishing handshakes could help reduce infections.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 29, 2017 - Hospital-acquired infections can be life-threatening, and unwashed hands are often to blame. One hospital in California thinks banishing handshakes could help reduce infections. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/29/529878742/handshake-free-zones-target-spread-of-germs-in-the-hospital

item.title: From NFL Player To Neurosurgeon: 'Why Can't I Do Both?'
item.description: May 28, 2017 - Myron Rolle talks about his long journey from playing football at Florida State University and joining the NFL to going to Harvard medical school to start his residency in neurosurgery.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 28, 2017 - Myron Rolle talks about his long journey from playing football at Florida State University and joining the NFL to going to Harvard medical school to start his residency in neurosurgery. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/28/530504767/from-nfl-player-to-neurosurgeon-why-cant-i-do-both

item.title: NASA Spacecraft Finds Storms On Jupiter
item.description: May 28, 2017 - Raging cyclones and an uneven magnetic field: NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks to NASA scientist Jack Connerney about the surprising findings made by a spacecraft orbiting Jupiter.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 28, 2017 - Raging cyclones and an uneven magnetic field: NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks to NASA scientist Jack Connerney about the surprising findings made by a spacecraft orbiting Jupiter. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/28/530447121/nasa-spacecraft-finds-storms-on-jupiter

item.title: In The Age Of Digital Medicine, The Humble Reflex Hammer Hangs On
item.description: May 28, 2017 - Nearly 130 years since its inception, a modest knob of rubber with a metal handle is still invaluable in diagnosing disease and avoiding expensive testing. But its history is anything but simple.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 28, 2017 - Nearly 130 years since its inception, a modest knob of rubber with a metal handle is still invaluable in diagnosing disease and avoiding expensive testing. item.title: How A Gene Editing Tool Went From Labs To A Middle-School Classroom
item.description: May 27, 2017 - Some compare the democratization of personal computing in the 1970s to the current changes in access to genetic engineering tools, in part thanks to the CRISPR gene editing tool.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: 2 Scientists, 2 Different Approaches To Saving Bees From Poison Dust
item.description: May 27, 2017 - Two scientists agree that pesticide-laden dust from planting equipment kills bees. But they're proposing different solutions, because they disagree about whether the pesticides are useful to farmers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 27, 2017 - Two scientists agree that pesticide-laden dust from planting equipment kills bees. But they're proposing different solutions, because they disagree about whether the pesticides are useful to farmers. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/27/530028003/two-scientists-two-different-approaches-to-saving-bees-from-poison-dust

item.title: Richard Dawkins On Terrorism And Religion
item.description: May 27, 2017 - Richard Dawkins, the scientist and outspoken atheist, speaks with NPR's Scott Simon about terrorism, and how the world has changed since he first began talking about his opposition to religion.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 27, 2017 - Richard Dawkins, the scientist and outspoken atheist, speaks with NPR's Scott Simon about terrorism, and how the world has changed since he first began talking about his opposition to religion. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/27/530337283/richard-dawkins-on-terrorism-and-religion

item.title: Market Forces May Impact Emissions More Than Climate Agreements
item.description: May 27, 2017 - Today President Trump is at the G-7 summit and high on the agenda is climate change. Many world leaders are imploring Trump stay in the global climate agreement, but emissions are going down already.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 27, 2017 - Today President Trump is at the G-7 summit and high on the agenda is climate change. Many world leaders are imploring Trump stay in the global climate agreement, but emissions are going down already. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/27/530337304/market-forces-may-impact-emissions-more-than-climate-agreements

item.title: As Brains Mature, More Robust Information Networks Boost Self-Control
item.description: May 26, 2017 - Sometime between grade school and grad school, the brain's information highways get remapped in a way that dramatically reins in impulsive behavior.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - Sometime between grade school and grad school, the brain's information highways get remapped in a way that dramatically reins in impulsive behavior. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/26/529828305/more-robust-information-networks-boost-self-control-as-brains-mature

item.title: Abigail Marsh: Are We Wired To Be Altruistic?
item.description: May 26, 2017 - When Abigail Marsh was 19, a complete stranger risked his life to save her from a car accident. Today, she studies what motivates us to help others — and why some of us are "extraordinary" altruists.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 26, 2017 - When Abigail Marsh was 19, a complete stranger risked his life to save her from a car accident. Today, she studies what motivates us to help others — and why some of us are "extraordinary" altruists. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/26/529957471/abigail-marsh-are-we-wired-to-be-altruistic

item.title: Scientists Pinpoint How A Flamingo Balances On One Leg
item.description: May 25, 2017 - What appears to be a feat actually requires almost no muscle effort from the bird. The researchers found even a dead flamingo's body will fall into a stable one-leg balance if positioned vertically.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 25, 2017 - What appears to be a feat actually requires almost no muscle effort from the bird. The researchers found even a dead flamingo's body will fall into a stable one-leg balance if positioned vertically. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/25/530046238/scientists-pinpoint-how-a-flamingo-balances-on-one-leg
